sentences.sentence: When the tea was finished, the card-tables were set up.
Elizabeth was hoping that Darcy would sit by her, but she saw him being forced by her mother to join her table.
In a few moments he was seated, and so was everybody else at the party.
She now had nothing else to look forward to that evening.
They were trapped for the evening at different tables.
She had no reason for hope, except that he occasionally looked toward her side of the room, and so was clearly as distracted( 分心的 ) from the card game as she was herself.
Mrs. Bennet had planned to keep the two gentlemen from Netherfield for supper, but unfortunately their carriage arrived before any of the others, and she had no opportunity to make them stay.
A few days after this visit, Mr. Bingley visited again, but this time he was alone.
Mrs. Bennet ran into her daughter’s room, wearing only her dressing gown( 睡袍 ) and with her hair half finished, and cried out:
“My dear Jane, finish dressing and hurry downstairs( 楼下 ).
He has come—Mr. Bingley has come.
He has, indeed.
Hurry up, hurry up.
Here, Sarah, come help Miss Bennet with her dress.
Forget about Miss Lizzy’s hair.”
But when her mother was gone, Jane refused to go down without one of her sisters.
Their mother’s desire to let the two potential( 潜在的 ) lovers be by themselves was far too obvious that evening.
After tea time was finished, Mr. Bennet went to the library, as was his custom.
Mary also went upstairs( 楼上 ) to practice her music.
Two obstacles( 障碍 ) out of the five had now been removed, and Mrs. Bennet then sat looking and winking( 眨眼 ) at Elizabeth and Catherine for quite some time,
but this did not have any effect.
Elizabeth refused to acknowledge( 理会 ) her.
When Kitty did at last, she very innocently said, “What is the matter, mamma( 妈妈 )? What do you keep winking( 眨眼 ) at me for? What should I do?”
“Nothing child, nothing.
I did not wink( 眨眼 ) at you.”
She then sat still for five more minutes, but was unable to waste such an opportunity, and so she suddenly stood up.
Saying to Kitty, “Come here, my love, I want to speak to you,” she took her out of the room.
Jane instantly gave a pleading( 恳求的 ) look to Elizabeth,
which showed her distress( 痛苦 ) at the obviousness( 显而易见 ) of her mother’s plan, and that she desperately( 绝望地 ) did not want Elizabeth to go along with it.
In a few minutes, however, Mrs. Bennet half-opened the door and called out:
“Lizzy, my dear, I want to speak with you.”
Elizabeth was thus forced to go.
“We might as well leave them by themselves you know,” said her mother, as soon as she was in the hall.
“Kitty and I are going upstairs( 楼上 ) to sit in my dressing-room.”
Elizabeth did not attempt to argue with her mother, but remained quietly in the hall.
When her mother and Kitty were out of sight, Elizabeth then returned into the drawing-room.
But when she reentered( 再次进入 ) the drawing-room, what she found there surprised her greatly, because she saw that her mother had in fact been too clever for her.
When she opened the door, she found her sister and Bingley standing together by the fireplace, looking as if they were in the middle of a very interesting conversation.
Even if this had not made Elizabeth suspicious( 起疑心的 ), the faces of both would have told her everything.
Elizabeth was about to go away again, when Bingley suddenly whispered a few words to her sister, and then rushed out of the room.
Jane could not keep secrets from Elizabeth, when she knew that telling the truth would give happiness.
She rushed to embrace( 拥抱 ) her, and with great excitement, she told Elizabeth that she was the happiest woman in the world.
“Would you believe it, Lizzy—when he went to London last November, he really loved me, and only his belief that I did not care for him prevented his coming back again!”
“He certainly made a mistake, but only because of his modesty.”
“It is too much!” Jane added,
“far too much.
I do not deserve it.
Oh! Why is everybody not this happy? I must go this instant to my mother,” she cried.
“I would not want her to hear it from anyone but myself.
He has gone to my father already.
Oh! Lizzy, if only I could see you so happy! If only there were such a man for you!”
“If you were to give me forty such men, I never could be so happy as you,” Elizabeth replied.
“Until I have your sweetness and your goodness, I never can have your happiness.
No, let me manage for myself, and, perhaps, if I am very lucky, I may meet with another Mr. Collins in time.”
Jane then rushed away to her mother, who was sitting upstairs( 楼上 ) with Kitty.
Elizabeth, who was left by herself, now smiled at how quickly and easily the matter had finally been settled.
The many previous months of suspense( 焦虑 ) and frustration( 沮丧 ) were finally over.
It was an evening of great delight for everybody.
Miss Bennet’s satisfaction made her face glow( 洋溢 ) with sweet enthusiasm, and this made her more beautiful than ever.
Mrs. Bennet could not voice her approval( 允许 ) of the marriage with enough warmth to express her true feelings( 感受 ), even after she had spoken to Bingley about it for over half an hour.
When Mr. Bennet joined them at supper, his voice and his look clearly showed how really happy he was.
He did not say a word about it, however, until Mr. Bingley went home later that night.
As soon as he was gone, however, he turned to his daughter, and said:
“Jane, I congratulate you.
You will be a very happy woman.”
Jane went to him instantly, kissed him, and thanked him for his goodness.
“You are a good girl,” he replied, “and it gives me great pleasure to know you will be so happily married.
I have no doubt you two will do very well together.
Your natures are both very similar.
You are both so agreeable, that you will never make any decisions;
so carefree( 无忧无虑的 ), that every servant will cheat you; and so generous, that you will always spend more than your income.”

article_info.previous: Lydia离开的日子到来了。重新令Mrs. Bennet感到兴奋的是Mr. Bingley和Mr. Darcy紧接着前来拜访了。之后在Longbourn的舞会上，Mr. Bingley像以前一样坐在了Jane的旁边，对Jane还是心存爱恋，而Mr. Darcy却似乎刻意避开Elizabeth。
article_info.share_words: Miss Bennet's satisfaction made her face glow with sweet enthusiasm, and this made her more beautiful than ever.

question.cn: 据Jane所述，什么阻止了Mr. Bingley的再次回归？
question.en: What prevented Mr. Bingley from returning according to Jane?

options.cn: 他没有足够支付旅程的钱。
options.en: He did not have enough money for the journey.
He fell in love with someone else.
He believed that Jane didn't care for him.

analysis: 文中Jane说到：“Would you believe it, Lizzy......he really loved me, and only his belief that I did not care for him prevented his coming back again!” 所以选C。

question.cn: Mr. Bennet怎么看待Jane和Mr. Bingley之间的关系？
question.en: What did Mr. Bennet think of the relationship between Jane and Mr. Bingley?

options.en: He was in favor of it.
He did not support the relationship.
He thought Mr. Darcy was better.

analysis: 文中提到：“When Mr. Bennet joined them at supper, his voice and his look clearly showed how really happy he was......‘Jane, I congratulate you. You will be a very happy woman.’” 所以选A。

question.cn: 他们为何没有留下吃晚饭？
question.en: Why didn’t the two gentlemen stay for supper?

options.cn: 因为他们马车到的比其他人早。
options.en: Because their carriage arrived before any of the others.

analysis: 原文可知“Mrs. Bennet had planned to keep the two gentlemen from Netherfield for supper, but unfortunately their carriage arrived before any of the others.”因此答案选B。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第96天
